review:
I was never exposed to the original Oregan Trail, but learning from media and from my peers, I understand quite well what core mechanics are involved.

I quite enjoy the whimsical humour and the writing/sci-fi theme of Orion Trail. So do I much appreciate the art direction.

However, I am immediately put off by how much "chance" dominates your outcomes on the trail, disregarding your decisions.

In fact, my frustration with the RNG factor is so intense, I de-installed the game after several attempts.

It seems that the decisions I made in investing in specfic areas of expertise DID NOT MATTER AT ALL, because of the random number generater. 

I'd much perfer a system similar to described;

Each mission for the moment have three possible solutions. Solutions involving expertise like "Science." or "Diplomacy". 

To successfully complete the actions required of that solution, player must meet the skill "threshold".

Example.

My crew has the combined expertise in Science of 4 after initial crew member assembly.

Second mission of the trail, I am asked to gain access to an alien fuel source, blocked by an alien bio-matching vault panel lock.

Choosing my "science" expertise solution, which is to surgically transplant an alien tentacle to a crew's body to operate alien technology, requires a total roll of 6.

Before the roll, my expertise in Science GUARANTEE 4 points in the roll. So I only need a minimum roll of "2" to succeed.

This way, if I heavily invest in some expertise, I actually get rewarded by it. And can feel safer to make those choices.



Right now, the Odds of the Orion Trail is TOO heavily stacked against us. May the travelers rest in pieces.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988353678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1521843229}
review:
This game is a lot like the original Oregon Trail - which it should be, since it's a space adventure based on it - only without the hunting.  Sorry, folks, that was a stretch goal that wasn't met.  Some people have complained that there's no skill involved, that it all comes down to a roll of the die.  This is broadly true, but aside from that sadly missing hunting game, Oregon Trail and the more recent "OMG anything is better with zombies" Organ Trail are pretty much the same way.  

Will you ford the river or try to float across?  Sneak through the horde of zombies or go through guns blazing?  Rely upon your attack rating and set phasers to "shave" or go with tactics and put on encounter suits to avoid the allergy problems from these furry trading aliens?  In each situation you know something about which will be more likely to succeed, but can ultimately fail based on luck... it's just that Oregon Trail is more open about that fact.

Despite the lack of hunting, I still think this is a good game.  You can't just min/max as another reviewer said because you won't always get the crew you want (you get a random assortment of three candidates for each slot), you may not have your impressive attack rating as an option each encounter, and going full-on diplomacy will leave you hurting when a bravado or science crisis hits.  You instead need to try to balance your various skills, knowing that going high on a couple of things will make those challenges more likely to succeed but that it will leave other stats weak.  And while a roll of the dice may not be an extremely exciting way to play a game, what you do have here is excellent writing.

Whether you're trying to escape being digested in the "Oh the huge manatee" event, finding that your shields can't hold against savings of this magnitude when a Megamart ship flies up or playing 'pop goes the warp weasel' when you chased the little pests into your airlock, there is a lot that's worth reading and a few chuckles involved.  Perhaps it won't be your favorite game to return to forever, but it's certainly worth playing for a few hours in my opinion.  And with more content slated to be added up through and past the official release, there should be plenty to do for $10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970094946', 'num_games_owned': 2748, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1443255049}
review:
I never thought I'd write a review about a game complaining about its RNG... I was wrong. 

The game takes the Oregon Trail formula and adds a hilarious sci-fi theme over top. That's about the only positive thing I can say about the game.

Your choices don't matter. You just tell the game which adventure you choose and it rolls the dice. The only strategy involved is trying to stack a certain stat to make the dice rolls more favorable. 

I would fail more often than not, even with the odds ridiculously stacked in my favor. I'm not sure if RNGesus has just forsaken me or if their random numbers aren't really that random. 

This game has an amusing concept, but as a game it's boring and frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126012738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1442702918}
review:
I played this game for 28 minutes. Enough time for two run-throughs. Time-wise, that was exactly what I was looking for in a game like this. I loved Organ Trail, even though I've only played it for 7 hours or so. I really enjoyed that game and was looking for something similar. This game was not it.

The problem with this game is it feels like soul-less RNG. There are no interesting decisions. Even picking your crew, you need to specialize to get the highest number possible in one category or another, meaning choosing a captain with a skill of 3, and a crew member with a skill of 2, with as much overlap in the same skill as possible, is a no-brainer. Combat basically amounts to rolling a die. Nothing you do can manipulate those odds. Planet exploration is the only interesting part of the game, but just barely. It amounts to a simple "press your luck" decision game. You can choose the path your spaceship takes, like sometimes... but the only decision there is to go to which resource you need most. And if the resource on both ends of the branch is the same, is that really much of a decision? You have no idea what sort of RNG event is going to happen or affect it in any way, so yeah... boring. By contrast, Organ Trail had lots of action-RPG events where you get rewarded for skillful gameplay and are constantly making decisions that affect your success.

In the end, this game plays itself. You're just there to watch and click buttons when necessary. No strategy. No tactics. Nothing. Really wanted to like this game. Didn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096079278', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1503883238}
review:
This is the first Kickstarter project I have ever contributed to as well as the first Early Access Game I have ever bought. I recommended it before, but now that it seems it is out of Early Access, I just can't recommend it anymore. It feels way too random. There just doesn't seem to be enough game here. You pick you captain and your officers, and you even get to rename them if you want. But the rest of the game is choosing which path to take and which stat (Attack, Science, Diplomacy, Bravado, etc.) that you are going to use to tackle the random events that crop up. After that it's all dice-rolling where the RNG feels like it, more often that not, works against you. And even now that Achievements have been activated, it doesn't really feel like any sort of actual achievement to get them. It seems like, if you just have enough playthroughs of the game, you'll get all of the achievements and nothing about your choices and skill will change that.

As for what I like about the game, there is the concept, which is basically "Oregon Trail In Space." I also like the visual style of the game; I am generally tired of all the indie games these days with their retro-pixelated graphics, but in this game I think it adds real charm. 

People have referred to FTL when talking about this game, but the graphics and the sense of humor bring to my mind the old Space Quest series by the Two Guys from Andromeda. Also, there is so much depth of gameplay in FTL that it makes this game seem like a computerized Choose Your Own Adventure book.

I can honestly say that I have had more fun playing an implementation of the original Oregon Trail on my crappy 5 year old phone than I have had with this game. It's too bad because I had high hopes for Orion Trail.

review:
4.5/5 Stars, rating based on game QUALITY not QUANTITY, unlike some people...

Knowing that the game is based strongly on elements the designers enjoyed from games like FTL and Oregan Trail helped me know what to expect (Kickstarter backer), but I admit that I was still pleasently surprised. While I have not found the game difficult to "beat" as far as individual missions go, I do admit that I find it difficult to actually keep more than just the captain alive! So if you are looking for something ridiculously hard, this isnt it. If you are looking for a choice based, text descriptive, tongue and cheek, slap stick sense of humor riddled game that sets you up to fail rather than win, this is the way to go.

The animations give a good sense of the characters (usually silly), the randomness of events helps keeps things fresh every time, and the completely random little additions and deductions on stats based on your gameplay help even more.

I would also like to add, that as a board gamer and ex-D&D splunker, I find the ability to see your ability modifiers affect your chances, and how the rolls go, to be a wonderful mechanic. It's a small thing, but I find it helps the occasionally 'slow' aspects of choice desicion to be rendered kind of fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068144977', 'num_games_owned': 804, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1485622823}
review:
I have left the original review below. As the game has now been released, this is what I now think of it:

It's really good!

All the extra content added since I last played it (life has been busy, so over a month ago!) really shows. The game is far better balanced, more polished, and it feels complete. The devs are still on top of things, making changes based on feedback, which is an extra point in my book. I am especially loving the added random encounters, which really add flavour to the game.

If you're looking for a funny, entertaining, space homage to Oregon Trail, this is your game. It is punishing at times, with a heavy RNG component, but your strategy will make a difference, and it is a hell of a lot of fun to play.


------------------------
At the moment this game is in early access, and it doesn't have as much content as it eventually will, but I still really like it, and I think it has great potential.

I was a Kickstarter backer, as I loved the concept, and so far it has stayed true to it. I really like the art style and the writing. The random encounters are witty and full of sci-fi references, which I love. I normally hold back from early access games, but I am glad to be part of the growth and evolution of this one.

I will update this review as the game progresses. At this point, I'd say: if you want to be active part of the development, and like the style and the concept, this is a perfect time to join in. If having little play content and some balance issues bothers you, perhaps sit back, keep an eye on the forums, and see how things evolve.

Update 1: after the first game update, I can already tell that the game feels far more solid. There is more content, everything feels far more balanced, and some of the ideas discussed in the forums have been implemented. Things are looking really good!

Update 2: after the last two updates, the game has noticeably more content. It feels much deeper and more replayable, and the addition of longer missions and extra encounters also up the challenge and the need to play more strategically, rather than relying on luck. I'm very happy with all the additions so far!

Der Grafikstil ist recht ansprechend.
Es hat einige witzige Anspielungen aus dem Sci-Fi und der Space Opera.
Jede Begegnung lässt sich auf unterschiedliche Weise lösen, und man darf nicht nur den Weg wählen, in dem man den höchsten Skill hat, sondern sollte sich auch über die Konsequenzen des jeweiligen Ansatzes Gedanken machen.

Mich stören aber auch einige Dinge.

Das Spiel ist stark abhängig von einem Zufallsgenerator. In einem Spiel habe ich keinen einzigen Erfolg gewürfelt.
Dabei stimmt auch das Balancing noch nicht ganz, da ich den Run trotzdem geschafft habe.... O.o
Bis jetzt sind noch zu wneig verschiedene Ereignisse im SPiel. In drei SPielen haben sich bereits einige Ereignisse mehrmals wiederholt, was dem Glücks-basierten Gameplay nicht sonderlich hilft.
Man kann abgesehen von der beschränkten Crew-Auswahl und den Entscheidungen während den Ereignissen nicht viel tun, um sein Schiff oder seine Crew aufzurüsten. Man ist somit immer vom Glück abhängig.

Außerdem sind bis jetzt nur 2 kleine Level verfügbar. 
Das Spiel ist gerade erst in den Early Access gegangen, also ist es zu erwarten, dass noch nicht viel vorhanden ist, aber vielleicht sollte man noch ein wenig warten, bevor man 10€ hierfür ausgibt.
Sollten noh mehr Ereignisse und Customization-Möglichkeiten eingebracht werden, könnte dies ein großartiges, FTL-artiges Spiel werden.
